results.title: Longing for belonging
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Jane Harrison and ACMI
results.brief_description: Jane Harrison’s search for belonging is a road trip with a lot of potholes along the way. Of mixed descent, she has longed to connect with her Indigenous heritage, which has forced her to confront some issues and attitudes within Australian society today.

results.title: Long weekend
results.brief_description: A young couple decide to spend a long weekend away in the bush together in an attempt to save their failing marriage. They head for a beach so isolated that even the locals have not heard of it. Strange things begin to happen, including the disappearance of their dog and then the girl herself. Cast includes John Hargreaves and Briony Behets.

results.title: Long way to the top: stories of Australian rock & roll
results.creator_credit: Greg Appel and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Compiled from the ABC-TV documentary series, “Long Way to the Top” is an in-depth visual and musical exploration of the cultural and creative explosion created by the arrival of the raucous, untameable voice of youth, otherwise known as rock and roll. Spanning the period 1956-2000 over six episodes, the series celebrates the evolution and re-interpretation of popular music and youth culture in Australia in the second half of the twentieth century. Not only a salute to Australian and New Zealand rock acts that achieved fame, this ‘rockumentary’ series also looks at the voices that struggled to be heard - the influence of the music of subcultures such as the hippies, punk, grunge and dance bands and the effect they have had in creating unique local sounds. Featured acts include: Johnny O’Keffe, Col Joye, Little Pattie, The Deltones, Billy Thorpe and the Aztecs, The Masters Apprentices, The Easybeats, The Seekers, Chain, Daddy Cool, AC/DC, Hush, Skyhooks, Rose Tattoo, The Angels, INXS, The Birthday Party, Midnight Oil, The Saints, The Models, Divinyls, Mental as Anything, Men at Work, Paul Kelly, Kylie Minogue, Nick Cave, Warumpi Band, The Cruel Sea and Silverchair. This version contains 1 hour extra material not seen in the original broadcast series. A comprehensive companion website to the series can be found at http://abc.net.au/longway/

constellations_primary.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_primary.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

results.description: Countdown (1974–87) was not only one of the first television programs in the world to regularly play music videos, but it also created clips for local acts such as It’s A Long Way To The Top (1976) for AC/DC. The footage of the band travelling down Melbourne’s Swanston Street on the back of a truck as they perform live became so iconic, it led to the city naming a key piece of geography after them in 2004: ACDC Lane.

results.title: Long term employment
results.creator_credit: Michael Farquhar and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Michael Farquhar walked into Brintons to leave his details at reception. The same day he had and interview and got a job. In his time there, he moved through many different areas and went through many life changes, from renting an appartment to marriage, owning a home and raising a family. When Brintons closed in 2008, Michael had worked there for 21 years. He talks about what it was like to work there, in the good and bad times.

results.title: Long night's journey into day
results.creator_credit: Iris Films, Cinemax Reel Life, Frances Reid, Johnny Symons and Deborah Hoffmann
results.brief_description: Powerful and poetic, heartbreaking and yet uplifting, this amazing documentary cannot help but stir your inner emotions and your conscience. For decades South Africa and black South Africans suffered at the hands of apartheid until the downfall of the white minority government. Those who perpetrated and enforced the rules of apartheid through torture, killing squads, imprisonment and death appealed for amnesty. As a compromise, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) was formed on the basis that amnesty would be considered on a case by case scenario in exchange for the truth. It’s role was to mediate between perpetrators of apartheid crimes who seek amnesty for their transgressions and the victims who seek justice. This resulted in a staggering number of over 22,000 victims telling their stories to the TRC but only around 7,000 perpetrators applying for amnesty. However the fact that the TRC existed at all enabled disclosure for some of the horrific events which took place, along with the telling fact that crimes were committed by not only whites, but blacks as well. This film centres on four vastly different case histories: Amy Biehl, an American exchange student murdered in 1993 by four young black men; Fort Calata, Matthew Goniwe (black activists) and two colleagues kidnapped and murdered in 1985 by five white police; Robert McBride an ANC militant activist responsible for a car bomb blast in 1985 killing three white women; and the government sanctioned killing of seven ANC “terrorists” by police including one black policeman. Uses archival and TRC trial footage, and features interviews with victims and perpetrators and their respective families, lawyers, journalists, TRC Commissioners and Archbishop Desmond Tutu (Chairperson). Forgiveness is not always forthcoming but at least humanity and truth are able to emerge through the establishment of the TRC and perhaps allow South Africa and all South Africans to move forward. Narrated by Helen Mirren. (Awards: Grand Jury Prize, Sundance Film Festival) Includes guidance notes for educational purposes. NOTE: Contains some disturbing images and recommended for mature audiences 15 years and over.
